content.raw:
I think the problem with the double pendulum is that here the `inertialPose` is in the link's local frame but the `box` is in the world /model frame. You can try different experiments rotating the pendulum to a different orientation before clicking to view the COM, and according to the pendulum's orientation the lines come up different:

![comsdoublep.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/1663405080-comsdoublep.png)
content.html: I think the problem with the double pendulum is that here the inertialPose is in the link's local frame but the box is in the world /model frame. You can try different experiments rotating the pendulum to a different orientation before clicking to view the COM, and according to the pendulum's orientation the lines come up different:

content.raw:
humm there are a couple of differences between this visualization and the one on `gzclient`, there, the mass is coming up as zero, so the sphere doesn't even show.

But regarding the rotation, you can see that the crossbar link has the Y axis pointing to the goal:

![rotgoal.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/937782189-rotgoal.png)

If you check the model, here's the rotation:

~~~
    <link name="crossbar">
      <pose>0 0 0.85 1.57 1.57 0</pose>
~~~

Links having rotation are quite common, so I'd say this is something we need to have well implemented before merging. Showing the wrong visualization is one of those things which could confuse users more than help them, because they will think there is a problem with their model, when the problem is the visualization.

Don't worry if you're blocked on this, focus on the other pull requests, and I can try taking a stab at this sometime soon.

Ok, so with the following patch, we can rotate the box to the link's frame and the lines get properly oriented (I also changed the order of the lines to have x-y-z):

diff -r 1284c06117e6 gz3d/src/gzscene.js
--- a/gz3d/src/gzscene.js   Wed Nov 01 18:52:39 2017 +0800
+++ b/gz3d/src/gzscene.js   Thu Nov 02 09:10:36 2017 -0700
@@ -2411,25 +2411,26 @@

         COMVisual.crossLines = [];
         box = new THREE.Box3();
+
         // w.r.t. world
         box.setFromObject(child);

-        // center vertices with object
-        box.min.x = box.min.x - model.position.x - child.position.x;
-        box.min.y = box.min.y - model.position.y - child.position.y;
-        box.min.z = box.min.z - model.position.z - child.position.z;
-        box.max.x = box.max.x - model.position.x - child.position.x;
-        box.max.y = box.max.y - model.position.y - child.position.y;
-        box.max.z = box.max.z - model.position.z - child.position.z;
+        // w.r.t. child
+        var worldToLocal = new THREE.Matrix4();
+        worldToLocal.getInverse(child.matrixWorld);
+        box.applyMatrix4(worldToLocal);

-        points[0] = new THREE.Vector3(inertialPose.position.x, box.min.y,
+        // X
+        points[0] = new THREE.Vector3(box.min.x, inertialPose.position.y,
           inertialPose.position.z);
-        points[1] = new THREE.Vector3(inertialPose.position.x, box.max.y,
+        points[1] = new THREE.Vector3(box.max.x, inertialPose.position.y,
           inertialPose.position.z);
-        points[2] = new THREE.Vector3(box.min.x, inertialPose.position.y,
+        // Y
+        points[2] = new THREE.Vector3(inertialPose.position.x, box.min.y,
           inertialPose.position.z);
-        points[3] = new THREE.Vector3(box.max.x, inertialPose.position.y,
+        points[3] = new THREE.Vector3(inertialPose.position.x, box.max.y,
           inertialPose.position.z);
+        // Z
         points[4] = new THREE.Vector3(inertialPose.position.x,
           inertialPose.position.y, box.min.z);
         points[5] = new THREE.Vector3(inertialPose.position.x,
@@ -2447,8 +2448,8 @@
         helperGeometry_3.vertices.push(points[4]);
         helperGeometry_3.vertices.push(points[5]);

-        var helperMaterial_1 = new THREE.LineBasicMaterial({color: 0x00ff00});
-        var helperMaterial_2 = new THREE.LineBasicMaterial({color: 0xff0000});
+        var helperMaterial_1 = new THREE.LineBasicMaterial({color: 0xff0000});
+        var helperMaterial_2 = new THREE.LineBasicMaterial({color: 0x00ff00});
         var helperMaterial_3 = new THREE.LineBasicMaterial({color: 0x0000ff});
         line_1 = new THREE.Line(helperGeometry_1, helperMaterial_1,
             THREE.LineSegments);

But you can see that the lines are wrongly scaled, this is especially visible for Y. This is happening because the bounding box we get with box.setFromObject is aligned with the world, so we're getting the first, but we want the second:

I haven't gone through the API searching for a way of getting this, do you know how to?

content.raw: From the test above `beforeAll` was removed, and for this one it is being added. Could you explain the reasoning a bit?
content.html: From the test above beforeAll was removed, and for this one it is being added. Could you explain the reasoning a bit?

content.raw: From the test above `beforeAll` was removed, and for this one it is being added. Could you explain the reasoning a bit?
content.html: From the test above beforeAll was removed, and for this one it is being added. Could you explain the reasoning a bit?

content.raw: So I remember finding out that using `beforeAll` here and using `var scene = new GZ3D.scene()` in the rest of the tests solved some problems with the tests, where the wrong objects were being called, because they were many of them, but some how this solved it allowing the right objects to be called.
content.html: So I remember finding out that using beforeAll here and using var scene = new GZ3D.scene() in the rest of the tests solved some problems with the tests, where the wrong objects were being called, because they were many of them, but some how this solved it allowing the right objects to be called.

There are a few problems with the math here:

  • The Z axis is being given special treatment, but we should account for rotations on all axes
  • This is setting the child's (link) local rotation with respect to the parent (model). If the model is not aligned with the world, we need to take that into account too.

You can easily see what's going on by commenting out the line which rotates the link back to its original rotation, and you'll see that the link is not properly aligned with the world the moment we take the bounding box.

Try out this patch:

diff -r 7e605fdee2ac gz3d/src/gzscene.js
--- a/gz3d/src/gzscene.js   Wed Nov 08 06:55:31 2017 +0800
+++ b/gz3d/src/gzscene.js   Thu Nov 09 09:20:57 2017 -0800
@@ -2411,17 +2411,19 @@

         COMVisual.crossLines = [];

-        // align the link with z axis and calculate its bounding box
+        // Store link's original rotation (w.r.t. the model)
         var originalRotation = new THREE.Euler();
-        var rot = new THREE.Euler();
+        originalRotation.copy(child.rotation);
+
+        // Align link with world (reverse parent rotation w.r.t. the world)
+        child.setRotationFromMatrix(
+            new THREE.Matrix4().getInverse(child.parent.matrixWorld));
+
+        // Get its bounding box
         box = new THREE.Box3();
-        originalRotation.copy(child.rotation);
-        rot.copy(child.rotation);
-        rot.set(0, 0, -originalRotation.z, 0);
-        child.setRotationFromEuler(rot);
-
         box.setFromObject(child);

+        // Rotate link back to its original rotation
         child.setRotationFromEuler(originalRotation);

         // w.r.t child

By setting the link's rotation to be the reverse of the parent's rotation in the world, we're addressing the 2 points above, see the results with many orientations:

content.raw:
I think we will need to use the same compute bounding box function as on pull request #130 to be sure we ignore the COM visual. I created a box with a dislocated COM and it affects the box:

![bbcom.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/3688785710-bbcom.png)

Quick way to test it:

1. Start gzserver, gzweb and gzclient
1. On gzclient, open the model editor
1. Insert a box
1. Double-click the box
1. Under the Link tab, change the inertial pose's Z to 2.0
1. Save and exit
1. Now on Gzweb, view COM
content.html:
I think we will need to use the same compute bounding box function as on pull request #130 to be sure we ignore the COM visual. I created a box with a dislocated COM and it affects the box:

Quick way to test it:

  1. Start gzserver, gzweb and gzclient
  2. On gzclient, open the model editor
  3. Insert a box
  4. Double-click the box
  5. Under the Link tab, change the inertial pose's Z to 2.0
  6. Save and exit
  7. Now on Gzweb, view COM
